Check this box to use the Steam Cloud system (remote file storage).
The Steam Cloud provides easy and transparent remote file storage for your game. Your save files will be replicated to the Steam servers after the game exits. If you then change computers, the files are downloaded to the new computer before the game launches.

The Steam Cloud provides easy and transparent remote file storage for your game. Your save files will be replicated to the Steam servers after the game exits. If you then change computers, the files are downloaded to the new computer before the game launches.

- The world has two continents. - All players start on the same continent, which can only contain these Strategic Resources: \7711\,\7712\; and only these Luxury Resources: \7721\,\7722\,\7723\,\7724\,\7725\. - The other continent could potentially contain all Strategic and Luxury Resources.
Everyone is starting on his own limited lands, looking for new way to expand.
- Each player starts alone on an island. - Starting islands do not contain any Strategic Resources. - There is a main continent that could potentially contain all Strategic Resources.
Start on one of the twin continents. Each continent is the perfect mirror of the other.

- The world has two continents which are identical in shape, geography, and resources. - The starting points on the map are symmetrical for empires of the same faction who are paired on the same line in the Opponents panel (slots 1 and 2, 3 and 4, 5 and 6, 7 and 8).

Level of difficulty of the enemy AI.
The only parameter available for this version of the game.
A house plant could beat it at chess.
If this was Henry V, the French would have won at Agincourt.
If the British had been like this, the US would still be a colony.
Every battle will feel like the Bulge.
So this is what it felt like to go up against Attila. And Genghis Khan.
If this was Leonidas, he might have won at Thermopylae.

Auriga is vast, but your empire is its equal. No other faction survives to pose a challenge to you for all of the cities and all of the settlers remaining upon this world are yours. Your domination of this world and responsibility for its future are absolute; victory is yours by complete elimination.

By gaining a level of mastery in the many complex elements of an empire - economy, military, sciences, etc. - you can create a civilization that is second to none. This victory will be given to the faction with the highest score after a fixed number of turns.
This victory is obtained by controlling a maximum of the surface of Auriga. Once a player has conquered 80% or more of the land regions of Auriga, they are victorious.

Through trade and development, you can enrich your empire to the point that all other peoples have no choice but to bow before the enormous power brought by your unimaginable wealth. Once you have generated enough Dust during the development of your empire, victory is yours!

By building alliances and friendships with other factions and empires, you become highly valuable as a friend and simply too dangerous as an enemy. When you have accumulated enough Diplomatic Points \7811\ in the great game of world diplomacy, you become the dominant political force of Auriga.

It is a building and an energy source and a processing center; a fusion of Dust and matter that transcends any existing knowledge. By reactivating this long-dormant temple of the Concrete Endless, a faction can secure the future of their planet - and at the same time be humbled by the vast gulf of ignorance that separates them from the long-lost masters who first built this marvel.

By researching increasingly complex scientific advances and developing increasingly sophisticated technology, you can arrive at a point where all other empires will be forced to acknowledge your mastery. Victory will be assured by discovering 5 researches in the 6th Era.

Dangerous and effective, your troops hold sway over all the centers of power on Auriga. In addition to your own capital city, you have also conquered the capitals of all the other empires upon the planet. Victory is yours!

If there is no way to save this dying planet, can you at least save your own people? Only by delving into the lost places of those who came before you can you hope of finding an answer to this ultimate question.
This determines the speed factor which affects different parameters: Population growth rate, Dust accumulation, research speed, and victory conditions.
The only parameter available for this version of the game.

The standalone mod defines all the Game mechanics. There must always be one and only one standalone mod at a time.
The partial conversion adds or overrides parts of the Game mechanics defined by the standalone mod. The partial conversion is optional. There can be only one partial conversion at a time.

Extension mods override or add parts of the Game mechanics defined by previous mods. There can be zero or any number of extension mods, provided they are compatible. Extensions usually provide minimal cumulative changes (additions, fixes...) that may be applied to other standalone or partial conversion mods.
Mods located in the "Community" directory, used for private tests and compatibility of our previous mods system.

This determines the world size. Will affect the victory conditions.

This determines how 'regular' the shape of the continent will be - are coastlines jagged or smooth, are changes in altitude abrupt or gradual, etc.
The continents will be more rounded or curved in shape, without internal seas or great changes of altitude.
Internal seas are possible, and some higher cliffs.
There will be internal seas, more random variations, and irregular continent shapes. Continents may be disproportionately sized and of varying distances from each other.
Internal seas, highly deformed continent shapes, and a great deal of randomness in altitudes. Distances between continents as well as their sizes can vary greatly.
The continent shape will be chosen randomly.
Intended for advanced players who would like to use additional options to customize the continent shapes.
Harsh with little Food, Industry, and Dust; rich in Science. Primarily Arctic and Tundra environments, little to no Jungle, no Desert.
Cold with little Dust and Science; a bit more Industry. Arctic and Tundra environments with some Highlands, little to no Jungle and Desert.
A variable climate with many different environments.
Dry; slightly better in Dust and worse in Science. Jungle and Desert environments with some Grassland, little to no Arctic or Tundra.
Hot with little Food and Science; rich in Dust. Primarily Desert and Jungle environments, little to no Tundra, no Arctic.
Temperate climate; very good for Food and Industry.
Warm and damp overall climate. Little to no Arctic and Desert, little Tundra or Arid.
The temperature will be chosen randomly.
Flat landscape. Rare elevations as high as 6 (out of 7). Few ridges and cliffs, all with maximum height of 2. Few rivers and lakes.
Moderately contoured landscape. Rare elevations as high as 7. Few ridges and cliffs, all with maximum height of 3. Occasional rivers and lakes.
Mountainous landscape (many elevation changes). Elevations often as high as 7. Many ridges and cliffs, all with maximum height of 4. Many rivers, few lakes.
Landscape with a higher proportion of hills. Occasional elevations as high as 7. Many ridges and cliffs, all with maximum height of 3. Some rivers and lakes.
The topography will be chosen randomly.
Intended for advanced players who would like to use additional options to customize the topography and geology of the game.
World Difficulty affects question of game balance and the relative 'fairness' of starting situations for all players.
Empires begin as far as possible from each other, there are many Resources and Anomalies, Minor Factions spawn less often and are less aggressive (slow to attack cities).

Some empires can begin closer to each other if that results in a better starting point for the faction based on the terrain. There should still be a minimum of 1 region between players if the region size is as recommended for the number of players.
There will be few Anomalies and Resources, and Minor Factions will spawn frequently and be aggressive.
Intended for advanced players who would like to use additional options to customize the difficulty level and the starting balance of the game.

At first, from the void, came the shape.
Within that shape, continents rose up from the seas...
...and within those continents, the regions were created.
Then the regions were covered by desert,
...and by hills and mountains that rose up to give my face a form.
Clouds drew together, rains fell, and the rivers swelled with water...
...and the lands grew wetter or drier as the rivers carved their way.
From beneath the crust of my skin precious resources thrust up.
Lesser species as well evolved and ranged across me,...
...and as all of these lived and grew and died they left their traces.
Lastly, for my children, I sowed places where my bounties could be easily reaped:
Bounties in minerals, in magics, in the wealth of the soil.
And when all was ready, and I saw that the world was rich, ...
...only then, were my children seeded upon it.
And then nothing remained but to wait, and to hope.
So the void became the shape, ...
Waiting for players to end their turn

Lists the Strategic Resources currently stored in your empire. Strategic Resources are exploited to build new Improvements or powerful equipment for your Units and Heroes.

Lists the Luxury Resources currently stored in your empire. Luxury Resources are used to provide bonuses to your empire, in the form of Boosters.
- Luxury Resources can be purchased at the marketplace or can be extracted if you have the required technologies. - To be used, Boosters must be activated from this screen. - Effects, cost and duration are detailed in the tooltip of each Booster. - Using additional Booster only increases the duration of the effect.

Lists the Stockpiles currently stored in your empire. These are used to boost your empire or cities with extra Food #CFE14F#\7700\#REVERT#, Industry #FF926D#\7701\#REVERT#, or Science #59DEFF#\7702\#REVERT#.
- Stockpiles can be purchased at the marketplace or can be built if you have the required technologies. - To be used, stockpiles must be activated from this screen. - Stockpiles have a base value of 100. - Stockpiles grant their bonus for 1 turn \7708\. - Using additional stockpiles on the same city only increases the duration of the effect and does not affect the amount of the resource generated per turn \7708\.

Displays the income generated by your trade routes.
Trade routes are automatic exchanges made between series of connected Cities (allies, friends and yours). This creates FIDS bonuses on Cities; both those creating routes and those crossed by them.
To obtain trade routes, you must have friendly cities connected through either land or ocean routes.
Cities will become connected if at least one paved road (from the "Right of Way" technology) or ocean route (from the "Cargo Docks" technology) links them together. - A paved road is made between two friendly adjacent cities with the "Right of Way" improvement . - An ocean road is made between two friendly cities with the "Cargo Docks" improvement. These cities can only be separated by a maximum of 2 ocean regions.
Click this button to display the list of your trade routes and their effects.

You don't have any trade routes yet.
To obtain trade routes, you must have friendly cities connected through either land or ocean roads.
Land trade routes can only be formed in between cities in adjacent regions with the "Right of way" city improvement built. Ocean trade routes can only be formed in between cities with the "Cargo Docks" district built, and if there is not more than one ocean region in between the two cities.

- The exploitation area and the regional buildings outside the city walls are no longer exploited. - Science and Dust produced by the city are divided by 2. - Each turn, the city loses Fortification points \7809\ equal to the Fortification Damage \7820\ of the besieger. Gives a bonus to an ally (Defense, Life, etc.).
Penalizes an enemy (removes Defense, slows Attack, etc.).
Removes life (Health Points) over a series of turns.
One of the ways to win the game.
Used to inflict Damage on enemies.
The one-handed Sword reduces the Defense of units it attacks and is particularly effective against Ranged units.
The two-handed Sword has a more powerful attack, reduces the Defense of units it attacks, and is particularly effective against Ranged units.
The Shield provides additional defense, whether the unit is defending or moving.
The one-handed Spear is particularly effective against Cavalry units.
The two-handed Spear has a more powerful attack and is particularly effective against Cavalry units.
The one-handed Staff is particularly effective against Ranged units.
The two-handed Staff has a better chance for a Critical hit and is particularly effective against Ranged units.
The one-handed Sceptre reduces Damage received and is particularly effective against units that use magic.
The two-handed Sceptre has a more powerful attack, reduces Damage received, and is particularly effective against units that use magic.
The one-handed Wand is particularly effective against Ranged units.
The two-handed Wand has a more powerful attack and is particularly effective against Ranged units.
The one-handed Axe reduces an enemy's Attack power and is particularly effective against Flying units.
The two-handed Axe has a more powerful attack, reduces an enemy's Attack power, and is particularly effective against Flying units.
The one-handed Claw allows units to Charge and is particularly effective against Cavalry units.
The one-handed Claw has a more powerful attack, allows units to Charge, and is particularly effective against Cavalry units.
The one-handed Hammer, though slow, is particularly effective against Melee units.
The two-handed Hammer, though slow, has a more powerful attack and is particularly effective against Melee units.
The one-handed Bow is particularly effective against Flying units.
The two-handed Bow has a better chance of a Critical hit and is particularly effective against Flying units.
The Crossbow has a shorter range but improved Damage and is particularly effective against Cavalry units

The fortification of the city \7809\. When the city is attacked, any unit defending it (including reinforcements) will have this fortification taking damage first, and when it is down to zero the unit will start to lose Health Points \7770\. At the end of the battle, the city's fortification \7809\ is reduced by the total fortification lost divided by the number of units using the fortification bonus on the defensive side.
Fortification \7809\: $CityDefenseValue

The fortification of the city \7809\. When the city is attacked, any unit defending it (including reinforcements) will have this fortification taking damage first, and when it is down to zero the unit will start to lose Health Points \7770\. At the end of the battle, the city's fortification \7809\ is reduced by the total fortification lost divided by the number of units using the fortification bonus on the defensive side.
A percentage of the Fortification value \7809\ is converted into $DefensivePowerValue Retaliation damage \7823\ inflicted to adjacent unfriendly armies.

A siege has started on one of your cities.
That city will suffer the following consequences: 1) Exploitation tiles are no longer productive; only tiles with Districts and the city center bring FIDSI. 2) All the regional buildings outside the city are disabled due to the loss of their connection with the city; their vision range is also set to 0. The regional buildings within a district are still active. 3) The city cannot build any more regional buildings. 4) Science and Dust produced are divided by 2. 5) The besieged city suffers from a loss of Approval. 6) Units within a besieged city or on a city tile have their regeneration disabled. 7) The city garrison cannot help in a battle, if the besieger is not related to it. 8) Each turn, the city loses Fortification points \7809\ equal to the Fortification Damage \7820\ of the besieger. Once the Fortification \7809\ is equal to 0, units within the city garrison OR on a city tile lose health each turn in proportion to the Fortification Damage \7820\. 9) The Governor (Hero) of a besieged city gains more experience

For a variable period (depending on game speed), empires cannot break this treaty without paying additional cost in Influence #8A7DFF#\7704\#REVERT#.
Allies earn Influence #8A7DFF#\7704\#REVERT# for each unit killed in battle against an ally's opponent (i.e. an empire in war or cold war with your ally).
An Alliance gives a certain amount of Influence #8A7DFF#\7704\#REVERT# per turn, with this amount increasing if the alliance lasts.
Map Exchange and Shared Vision treaties are automatically ratified for free (no additional Influence #8A7DFF#\7704\#REVERT# cost).
A Closed Border treaty is automatically broken (at no additional cost in Influence #8A7DFF#\7704\#REVERT#) when applicable, or cannot be ratified, if you enter an Alliance.
In addition, an Alliance provides all of the advantages of a Peace treaty.
Alliance provides 4 Diplomatic Points \7811\ per turn \7708\.

For a variable period (depending on game speed), two empires cannot attack each other without breaking the treaty and paying additional cost in Influence #8A7DFF#\7704\#REVERT#.
Trade Routes are activated between the 2 empires (provides Dust #FFD768#\7703\#REVERT# and Science #59DEFF#\7702\#REVERT# mutual bonus).
New treaties can be ratified (commercial agreements, etc.).
Peace provides 2 Diplomatic Points \7811\ per turn \7708\.

During this period, empires can attack each others' armies within non-colonized regions, without declaring war on each other. An empire can freely attack enemies in its regions.
A Player's armies can roam freely in the regions of other Empires with whom the Player is at Cold War.
Cold War provides 1 Diplomatic Point \7811\ per turn \7708\.

Empires in a state of Truce cannot attack each other for a period of several turns \7708\, depending on the Game Speed, without breaking the Truce and paying additional cost in Influence #8A7DFF#\7704\#REVERT#.
Peace or Alliance cannot be proposed during a state of Truce.
Truce provides 1 Diplomatic Point \7811\ per turn \7708\.

War is automatically declared if an Empire attacks armies inside their owner's region (this includes City siege and assault).
Except Truce, no other treaties can be ratified when the diplomatic status is War.
War provides 1 Diplomatic Point \7811\ per turn \7708\.

#FFFFFF#\7802\#REVERT# Tip: During the battle Targeting Phase, you can select a position (right-click #FFFFFF#\9997\#REVERT#) and then select a target unit (Ctrl + right-click #FFFFFF#\9997\#REVERT#) in order to give more precise orders.
#FFFFFF#\7802\#REVERT# Tip: Building a Settler consumes all the Food #CFE14F#\7700\#REVERT# production, so you can assign your workers \7705\ to other resources through the worker panel.
#FFFFFF#\7802\#REVERT# Tip: Exploiting the terrain can be critical to your success. Choose the position of your City \7782\ carefully, taking into account anomalies, rivers, lakes, etc.

#FFFFFF#\7802\#REVERT# Tip: Expanding too quickly will make your Approval #F0A1FF#\7706\#REVERT# plummet, greatly reducing your overall Food #CFE14F#\7700\#REVERT# and Industry #FF926D#\7701\#REVERT# production.
#FFFFFF#\7802\#REVERT# Tip: Using advanced Unit Designs \7766\ and Hero \7764\ Equipment can give a huge military advantage to your armies.
#FFFFFF#\7802\#REVERT# Tip: To better protect your Cities \7782\, improve their Fortifications and keep more than just the Militia units in the garrison.
#FFFFFF#\7802\#REVERT# Tip: To finish a siege more quickly, move additional Armies \7766\ next to the City Districts \7782\, on the Exploitation Area \7759\, as each unit will add 1 Siege point.
#FFFFFF#\7802\#REVERT# Tip: During a siege, once a city's Fortifications have fallen, Units \7766\ in the city garrison start taking Damage \7776\.
#FFFFFF#\7802\#REVERT# Tip: Killing units of an ally's enemy and keeping an Alliance \7758\ going are both ways to collect additional Influence #8A7DFF#\7704\#REVERT# income turn after turn.
#FFFFFF#\7802\#REVERT# Tip: For better trade income, a city's Trade Routes \7756\ will always connect to the most distant cities with the highest Population \7705\.
#FFFFFF#\7802\#REVERT# Tip: Don't forget your Upkeep costs \7707\. Everything costs a bit of Dust #FFD768#\7703\#REVERT# on Auriga, from City Improvements to Armies, Units and Heroes.

#FFFFFF#\7802\#REVERT# Tip: Sending Diplomatic Warnings or Compliments \7758\ to other Empires \7765\ will affect the cost of future diplomatic actions; after sending a Warning, for example, it is less expensive to declare war.
#FFFFFF#\7802\#REVERT# Tip: You can rename Armies \7766\ and Cities \7782\ / You can toggle the interface by pressing Ctrl+F10
#FFFFFF#\7802\#REVERT# Tip: Heroes \7764\ earn bonus XP each turn for commanding an Army \7766\ or ruling a City \7782\. The larger the Army or Garrison, the bigger the bonus.
#FFFFFF#\7802\#REVERT# Tip: The more friendly units surround a unit in battle, the higher its Morale \7789\ is.
#FFFFFF#\7802\#REVERT# Tip: A high damage \7776\ Unit can miss if its Attack \7772\ is much lower than an enemy's Unit Defense \7773\.
#FFFFFF#\7802\#REVERT# Tip: The more Cities \7782\ you have, the higher the costs for Luxury boosters, the Empire Plan, and Diplomatic actions.
#FFFFFF#\7802\#REVERT# Tip: The Worker Panel as well as the Construction Queue of each city can be managed directly from your City List Screen.
#FFFFFF#\7802\#REVERT# Tip: You can save some production by building a City District \7745\ instead of an Extractor on top of a Strategic or a Luxury Resource \7781\.
#FFFFFF#\7802\#REVERT# Tip: You cannot expand your City over Ruins \7777\ or Villages \7738\. However, they can be exploited like any other terrains when located next to City Districts \7745\.

#FFFFFF#\7802\#REVERT# Tip: Within your Empire \7765\ territory, you can use the Retrofit button in your army panel or on the Military Screen in order to ugrade a unit to a new unit design you have created. It will cost Dust #FFD768#\7703\#REVERT# in place of Industry #FF926D#\7701\#REVERT#.
#FFFFFF#\7802\#REVERT# Tip: You can destroy Cities \7782\ without declaring war by using a mercenary army turned into Privateers \7785\.

#FFFFFF#\7802\#REVERT# Tip: All Factions have unique Technologies \7763\ that can be researched, such as the Necrophages' ability \7793\ to sacrifice their City Workers \7705\ to gain Approval #F0A1FF#\7706\#REVERT#.
#FFFFFF#\7802\#REVERT# Tip: As mercenaries, units coming from converted Villages \7738\ can be used as Privateers \7785\.
#FFFFFF#\7802\#REVERT# Tip: Your attitude and behavior towards each Empire \7765\ have a direct impact on the cost in Influence #8A7DFF#\7704\#REVERT# of diplomatic actions.
#FFFFFF#\7802\#REVERT# Tip: The Dark Season is getting longer and longer and occurs more frequent during the course of the game. Be careful to plan for its effects ahead of time.
#FFFFFF#\7802\#REVERT# Tip: Within your Empire \7765\, the more you pacify Villages \7738\ of one Minor Faction \7780\, the lower their Unit \7766\ construction cost will be.
#FFFFFF#\7802\#REVERT# Tip: If you use a Roving Clans \7794\ Setseke within the same region, your Extractors and Watchtowers will also be preserved.
#FFFFFF#\7802\#REVERT# Tip: Use the Enter key to open the in-game console and enter the "/?" command to display a list of all available commands.

With Dust already writhing beneath their great suits of armor, it is no surprise that Dust Eclipses can have such great impacts on the Broken Lords' armies.
During Eclipses units and heroes gain a new army action, Soul Burn, that greatly boosts their attack at the expense of their health.
When Dust Eclipses descend on Auriga, animating forces bring to life some of corpses of the Necrophages' great heaps of flesh, creating not-so-fresh recruits.
During Eclipses, Recycled Stockpiles create 2 Battle Borns in the target city in addition to the Food bonus and combat yield twice the cadavers
Responding to Auriga's apparent distress, the Allayi are moved to great feats of endurance during Dust Eclipses.
During Eclipses armies gain +2 Movement and an additional Action Point
Leveraging the feelings of fanaticism that Dust Eclipses instill in Auriga's lesser races, Cultists preach that they are a sign from the Queen.
During Eclipses, Minor Faction units gain 10% attack, damage, defense and health per capital's City level
With greatly heightened senses during Dust Eclipses, Wild Walkers are carefully attuned to Auriga's other inhabitants, granting them the capacity to meet the enemy head-on.
During Eclipses, Sharing ability is active on all regions of the map and movement through forest cost 0.5 instead of 2
As natural seafarers, the Morgawr are the only faction able to take advantage of the high winds and rough seas that characterise the oceans during Dust Eclipses.
During Eclipses gain +4 Embarked Movement on the seas
Powerful currents of Dust in the air during Dust Eclipses greatly enhance the accuracy of Vaulter teleportation, allowing more target destinations.
During Eclipses, while the Holy Resource Boost is active, Vaulters can teleport units directly to any Army with an assigned hero in the field

Taking advantage of Dust's magical propensity to literally drift out of imperial coffers during Eclipses, infiltrated Forgotten spies can potentially steal small fortunes during the long twilight night.
During Eclipses, infiltrated Forgotten spies gain the Dust Opportunists Infiltration Action, allowing to steal Dust from other empires.
Building off pain rituals, during Dust Eclipses injured Ardent Mages find themselves driven into violent rages that make them extra dangerous fighters.
During Eclipses units with low health enjoy bonus Damage as well as attack from Ardent Fire
Already well-attuned to earthen energies, Kapaku shamans gain near supernatural powers of insight at times of Dust Eclipse.
During Eclipses, Kapaku shamans can locate confluxes in their own and explored neighboring regions, and enjoy increased effects from these confluxes.
A master craftsman wastes no materials, and this faction is no different. After a siege, shattered walls, crumbled towers, and fallen battlements are all grist for the industrial mill.

Capricious stone beasts from the subterranean realm, the three Urkans are ancient creatures who periodically emerge onto the surface of Auriga.
Opens the Urkan Training screen to see available upgrades for the Urkans.
The amount of Industry gained from Organic Industry.

The ancient Urkan beasts are stirring. As violent tremors shake the ground, frightened surface dwellers whisper that the fabled creatures may be more than just myths. Soon one will surely break through the crust, bringing a threat --and an opportunity-- for all Auriga's races.
Breaking through the crust, the ancient Urkan beast's roar echoes across the lands. Where will it burrow next, and will it be a danger or a boon for your empire?

Urkans are powerful creatures that make it impossible to settle on a region they currently inhabit. After several turns, untamed Urkans move regions. They can be tamed by defeating them in combat or giving them luxury resources. Once tamed, the Urkan will give you the resources available on the region, and you can unlock further powers for the Urkan by expending luxuries.
Urkans suffer 25% penalty on all their stats during winter Untamed Urkans will not migrate during winter
The Urkan, {0}, has been tamed by the {1} Empire and is now under their command.
A Fungal Bloom has been completed!
A Fungal Bloom has finished its growing process and is now at its full potential.

The Mykara use Food #CFE14F#\7700\#REVERT# from their unique city to exploit points of interests in unexploited regions. Although captured cities cannot be further developed, they still grant their tile outputs and allow the symbiosis of other factions. To be the most effective, the Mykara seek to control the Urkans.

The Wild Walkers rely on forests, to get more Industry #FF926D#\7701\#REVERT# and build faster, but also to gain advantage in battle. Masters of their environment, they can locate enemy armies near their cities, even through the fog of war.

The Broken Lords have no use of Food #CFE14F#\7700\#REVERT#. To sustain themselves, they require Dust #FFD768#\7703\#REVERT# --both to create their population and to regenerate their units through Life draining.

By selecting one Strategic Resource as a Holy Resource \7710\, the Vaulters can use it far beyond common understanding. They can create unique unit designs and city improvements or even teleporting armies that can instantly move between cities. Defense and research are also part of their main strengths.

The Necrophages always seek for Food #CFE14F#\7700\#REVERT# to proliferate. To sate their hunger, they can consume enemy units they kill, but also rely on populations coming from villages. They can't negotiate any kind of peace, always acting with aggression towards other livings beings.

As masters of magic, the Ardent Mages can place pillars on the map to increase outputs or reduce movement costs. In combat, they can use their unique spells, but also raise their combativity when suffering damage.

The Roving Clans can relocate their cities at will. They tax every market transaction and can ban other empires' use of the marketplace. However, as wise merchants, they will also never decide to go to war.

As old and ancient creatures, the Drakkens have the immediate knowlegde of any living major empire and see one tier further in their Empire Plan. By using Influence #8A7DFF#\7704\#REVERT#, they can also impose peaceful diplomacy on other empires.

Limited to a single city, the Cultists instantly destroy any city they defeat. To sustain their economy, their armies must convert pacified minor faction villages by spending Influence #8A7DFF#\7704\#REVERT#.

By selecting one Strategic Resource as a Holy Resource \7710\, the Mezari can use it far beyond common understanding. They can create unique unit designs and city improvements or even teleporting armies that can instantly move between cities. Defense and research are also part of their main strengths.

The Forgotten don't gather and use Science #59DEFF#\7702\#REVERT#. Yet, they can buyout technologies using Dust #FFD768#\7703\#REVERT#. They can also rely on their unit invisibility and Hero skills to better pillage and infiltrate other empires.

To sustain and extend their cities, the Allayi must use the Auriga Pearls, a resource that only spawns on the map in winter. Thankfully, they can also perfectly predict winters. They automatically adapt their abilities and appearance when winter arrives.

The Morgawr are intimately linked to water, getting huge Science #59DEFF#\7702\#REVERT# and Industry #FF926D#\7701\#REVERT# bonuses for exploiting sea tiles. They can also freely embark and move faster on rivers. They use psychic abilities to control minor factions and manipulate major ones.

Untamed Urkans move between neutral regions they control every once in a while, spawning roaming armies of lice every so often. Urkans can be tamed either by combat or by feeding them with specific luxury resources. Once tamed, they grant the luxury and strategic resources of the region they control, can be relocated or can switch into their army form. The Urkan Training screen, accessible from the Urkan on the map, also gives access to new powers to unlock.
